title: River waters cleanse spirits at India festival
text:
River waters cleanse spirits at India festival Originally published August 28, 2015 at 1:15 pm Updated August 28, 2015 at 1:58 pm A Hindu devotee performs a ritual in the Godavari River during Kumbh Mela, or Pitcher Festival, in Nasik, India, earlier this week. Millions of Hindus are expected to immerse themselves in the Godavari River as a way to cleanse themselves of sin and come closer to God at this year’s Kumbh Mela festival. (Bernat Armangue/AP) Hindu pilgrims arrive at a train station in Nasik, India, Friday, Aug. 28, 2015. Millions of Hindu pilgrims are expected at the Kumbh Mela, or the Pitcher festival, held this year along the Godavari River in Maharashtra state. (Bernat Armangue/AP) A Hindu devotee performs a holy dip in the Godavari River during Kumbh Mela on Aug. 26, or Pitcher Festival, in Nasik, India. Millions of Hindus are expected to immerse themselves in the Godavari River as a way to cleanse themselves of sin and come closer to God at this year’s Kumbh Mela festival. (Bernat Armangue/AP) A Naga sadhu, or naked Hindu holy man, performs a ritual inside his tent during Kumbh Mela, or Pitcher festival, at Trimbakeshwar, India, Friday, Aug. 28, 2015. Hindus believe taking a dip in the waters of a holy river during the festival will cleanse them of their sins. The festival is held four times every 12 years. (Rajanish Kakade/AP) Indians walk past posters of various holy men during the two-month long Kumbh Mela, or Pitcher festival, in Nasik, India, Friday, Aug. 28, 2015. Millions of Hindu pilgrims are expected at the festival held this year along the Godavari River in Maharashtra state. The festival is held four times every 12 years. (Bernat Armangue/AP) 0 of 0 Millions of Hindus are expected to join India’s two-month-long Kumbh Mela festival and immerse themselves in the Godavari river. By BERNAT ARMANGUE Associated Press 
NASIK, India — It’s just water. But to the millions of Hindus expected at the Kumbh Mela festival, held this year along the Godavari, touching that water is reverential. 
It’s a way to cleanse themselves of sin, to come close to God, to immerse themselves in a tradition that dates to antiquity. They have come to this city from across India and around the world. Entire villages arrive together, and their parties often last through the nights. Thousands of mystics gather. 
Water is central to many religions: Christians perform baptisms, Orthodox Jews seek ritual purity in mikvah baths, Muslims wash themselves before prayer. Believers in both Catholicism and voodoo find solace in the waters of Haiti’s Saut d’Eau waterfall. 
Observant Hindus believe that four drops of holy nectar were spilled long ago during a battle between gods and demons. Since then, the Kumbh Mela has alternated between the four cities where the nectar fell. Traveling in India 
Chaos, kindness and beauty in a Rajasthan journey . 
This year, the two-month festival is being held in the crowded city of Nasik. A Hindu devotee performs a holy dip in the Godavari River during Kumbh Mela on Aug. 26, or Pitcher Festival, in Nasik, India. Millions of Hindus are expected to immerse themselves in the Godavari River as a way to cleanse themselves of sin and come closer to God at this year’s Kumbh Mela festival. (Bernat Armangue/AP) 
The moment when people immerse themselves is the culmination of all the travel and effort and prayer, and the dark water of the Godavari sparkles from the splash. Some people thrust themselves almost violently in and out of the water. Some go delicately. Some take a gentle swim. 
Authorities are testing the water for pathogens every few hours, and insist contaminants are at “safe levels.” Many rivers across India have become foul with the country’s economic development, with city sewage, farming pesticides and industrial effluents freely flowing into waterways despite laws against polluting. BERNAT ARMANGUE
